user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_queue_auth_fail_response:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_queue_auth_fail_response (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                              const char *realm,
                              const char *opaque,
                              struct MHD_Response *response,
                              int signal_stale)
{
  return MHD_queue_auth_fail_response2 (connection,
                                        realm,
                                        opaque,
                                        response,
                                        signal_stale,
                                        MHD_DIGEST_ALG_MD5);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_queue_auth_fail_response:
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_queue_auth_fail_response2 (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                               const char *realm,
                               const char *opaque,
                               struct MHD_Response *response,
                               int signal_stale,
                               enum MHD_DigestAuthAlgorithm algo)
{
  enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiAlgo3 algo3;

  if (MHD_DIGEST_ALG_MD5 == algo)
    algo3 = MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_MULT_ALGO3_MD5;
  else if (MHD_DIGEST_ALG_SHA256 == algo)
    algo3 = MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_MULT_ALGO3_SHA256;
  else if (MHD_DIGEST_ALG_AUTO == algo)
    algo3 = MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_MULT_ALGO3_ANY_NON_SESSION;
  else
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Wrong algo value.\n")); /* API violation! */

  return MHD_queue_auth_required_response3 (connection, realm, opaque,
                                            NULL, response, signal_stale,
                                            MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_MULT_QOP_AUTH,
                                            algo3,
                                            0, 0);
}
...
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_queue_auth_required_response3 (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                                   const char *realm,
                                   const char *opaque,
                                   const char *domain,
                                   struct MHD_Response *response,
                                   int signal_stale,
                                   enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiQOP mqop,
                                   enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiAlgo3 malgo3,
                                   int userhash_support,
                                   int prefer_utf8)
{
  struct DigestAlgorithm da;
  char *buf_ptr;
  enum MHD_Result ret;

  buf_ptr = NULL;
  digest_setup_zero (&da);
  ret = queue_auth_required_response3_inner (connection,
                                             realm,
                                             opaque,
                                             domain,
                                             response,
                                             signal_stale,
                                             mqop,
                                             malgo3,
                                             userhash_support,
                                             prefer_utf8,
                                             &buf_ptr,
                                             &da);
  digest_deinit (&da);
  if (NULL != buf_ptr)
    free (buf_ptr);
  return ret;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the provided code fragments (MHD_queue_auth_fail_response, MHD_queue_auth_fail_response2, and MHD_queue_auth_required_response3). None of these fragments contain any use of the Standard Library function memcmp, nor do they perform direct comparisons of null‑terminated strings via memcmp. The only places that could potentially perform such a forbidden comparison are the functions called by these fragments that are not shown here. Specifically, queue_auth_required_response3_inner is invoked while being passed realm/opaque/domain (null‑terminated strings), so its implementation should be inspected for any memcmp usage comparing null‑terminated strings. Other helper calls shown (digest_setup_zero, digest_deinit, free) and the simple wrapper MHD_queue_auth_fail_response do not use memcmp and therefore do not need further investigation for Rule 21.14 based on the provided code.
